docs.lead_paragraph: My mother died of emphysema a couple of years ago. I was there when she died and the image of her gasping for breath will not go away. But what clings to me even more is the grief I feel about what she felt about her death, which was shame.

headline.main: In a Judgmental World, She Was Ashamed of Getting Sick

docs.abstract: Gretchen Cook Cases column talks about death of her mother from emphysema; asserts that patients who are ill from diseases linked to life style choices, like smoking, experience guilt and feel they caused their own illness; some doctors feel it is better for some patients to not know exact cause of illness; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Is there is a link between the shame a patient feels and the course of an illness?

docs.lead_paragraph: People who eat food high in antioxidant vitamins and minerals have been shown to have a lower incidence of cancer. But can there be too much of a good thing? A new study in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute found that when cancer patients took high doses of vitamin E, their risk of a new cancer actually went up. The study was led by Dr. Isabelle Bairati of Laval University in Quebec.
docs.abstract: Dr Isabelle Bairati of Laval University leads study that suggests patients with cancer who take high doses of vitamin E are twice as likely to develop new cancer than those who do not take high doses of vitamin supplements; study is published in Journal of the National Cancer Institute (S)
docs.snippet: People who eat food high in antioxidant vitamins and minerals have been shown to have a lower incidence of cancer. But can there be too much of a good thing?

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
